Award.AwardTitle: CBMS Conference: Computational Methods in Optimal Control
Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation award supports a 5-day CBMS conference on "Computational Methods in Optimal Control", to be held at the Jackson State University, Jackson, Mississippi, during July, 2018. The principal lecturer will be Dr. William W. Hager from the University of Florida. As one of the largest Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) in the United States, Jackson State University is a good location for hosting this conference, which will have a direct impact on training and attracting African-American students in the computational mathematics and statistical sciences doctoral programs and professions. The anticipated participants include senior and junior faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students. Some travel support will be provided to selected participants based on several criteria, such as relevance of research background, academic preparation, potential of long-term collaboration, and broader impacts.

Due to the growing complexity of optimal control applications, approximate solutions are often obtained by numerical algorithms, which requires deep understanding of numerical discretization and solution techniques. Dr. Hager will deliver ten main lectures on state-of-the-art computational methods on optimal control during the morning sessions, which are accompanied with guided computer lab sessions in the afternoon focusing on computer implementations of the discussed algorithms. The presented lectures and the corresponding monograph will provide both the background needed to analyze convergence of discrete approximations and solution techniques in optimal control, and practical experience in solving real-world problems. To complement the content of the main lectures, a few invited speakers will give additional introductory talks that focus on efficient numerical methods for solving optimal control problems whose dynamics are described by a partial differential equation. More information can be found at the conference website: http://www.siue.edu/~juliu/cbms18

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported Jackson State University to host the 2018 NSF-CBMS Regional Conference on Computational Methods in Optimal Control from July 23-27, 2018 with Dr. William Hager of the University of Florida as the main lecturer. Due to the growing complexity of optimal control applications, approximate solutions are often obtained by numerical algorithms, which requires deep understanding of numerical discretization and numerical optimization techniques. With this focus in mind, Dr. Hager delivered ten illuminating main lectures on the state-of-the-art computational methods on optimal control during the morning sessions. Each lecture topic was accompanied by a guided computer lab session in the afternoon focusing on computer implementations of the discussed algorithms based on the GPOPS-II package. The lab sessions were led by Dr. Anil Rao, also of the University of Florida. The lectures which will be monographed in the CBMS Regional Conference Series provided both the mathematical and numerical background needed to analyze the convergence of discrete approximations and solution techniques in optimal control, and practical experience in using the GPOPS-II package to solve real-world problems.

In the series, one will find that Dr. Hager developed a unified approach to investigating optimal control problems which emphasize on the interplay between discretization and optimization in numerical computation. The aim throughout the presentations is to provide participants and future readers with a framework within which computational methods in optimal control can be fully explored and understood. While the more theoretically oriented topics of the lectures have appealing mathematical flavor, the material, in general, is presented in such a way that participants and future readers of the monograph with less mathematical inclinations can still follow without losing the main theme of the lecture series. Dr. Hager's lectures were extended by original contributions from Dr. Mathias Heinkenschloss of Rice University, Dr. Michael Hinze of the University of Hamburg, Germany, Dr. Suzanne Lenhart of the University of Tennessee, and Dr. Dimitriy Leykekhman of the University of Connecticut, detailing various applications of optimal control computational methods to Bang-bang opimal control of parabolic partial differential equations, applications of optimal control in biological models, and numerical algorithms for partial differential equations-constrained optimization.

The conference attracted 53 participants across the southern United States ranging from beginning graduate students to seasoned professors with interest in computational methods, theory, and applications of optimal control. Upon careful selection, twenty-five of the participants were supported by NSF funding (including travel, lodging, and meals). Jackson State University graduate students in the Computational Data-enabled Science and Engineering Ph.D. program and faculty also attended the conference. Additional complemetary lectures related to numerical optimal control were also given by early career faculty member participants and advanced graduate students. The slides of the main lecture series and complenetary talks are posted on the conference website.
